Award.AwardTitle: Colloborative Research: Assessing Climate Model Simulations of Last Glacial Maximum Ocean Circulation with Carbon Isotopes
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the key premises in paleoclimatology is that understanding of past climate can give us insight into present day and future climate. A corollary is that the ability of climate models to faithfully simulate past climate, particularly during extreme periods such as the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM; ~20,000 years ago), will help us improve these models and give us more confidence in their projections of future climate change. Over the past few decades scientists around the world have periodically carried out an intercomparison of the latest model simulations of climate over the past few centuries and the future. In its most recent iteration (the Intergovernmental Panel of Climate Change Fifth Assessment Report, or IPCC AR5), this exercise also includes simulations of climate during the last glacial period (the Paleoclimate Model Intercomparison Project- Phase 3, or PMIP3).

The primary goal of this project, a collaboration between researchers from Columbia University's Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory and Oregon State University, is to evaluate the ability of the AR5 and PMIP3 suite of climate models to simulate the modern and LGM global ocean circulation. The goal is to both assess the state-of-the-art models used to project future climate change, as well as to contribute to a better understanding of climate and ocean circulation during the LGM. Previous assessments have been hampered by the lack of direct observations of past climates. Fortunately, the interaction of ocean circulation with carbon dioxide and other biogeochemical trace material leaves behind chemical signatures in ocean sediments that record the climate and ocean circulation of that period. Unfortunately, while scientists have become quite adept at measuring them, these chemical signatures are only indirect and imprecise recorders of ambient climate. To get around this problem, the researchers have developed a model capable of directly simulating biogeochemical tracers and their interaction with ocean circulation. Coupled with a novel computational technique, the researchers will simulate these tracers in the AR5 and PMIP3 models, and then compare them directly to the chemical signatures measured in sediments. By analyzing the results the researchers will be able to characterize the circulation of each model, identify the underlying factors responsible, and assess its performance against observed data.

The work is highly relevant to ongoing efforts to more accurately constrain past climates, to project the future impact of human activity on the climate system, and to develop models capable of simulating different climate regimes. The work involves collaboration with climate modeling groups around the world (Germany, Japan, France, and Australia).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project has contributed to a better understanding of the global ocean meridional overturning circulation (MOC) during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM), its driving forces, and its impacts on the carbon cycle. Figure 1 illustrates that current climate models from the Paleoclimae Model Intercomparison Project 3 (PMIP3) simulate a stronger and deeper Atlantic MOC during the LGM compared to today. A model of ocean circulation constrained by carbon isotope data from LGM sediments, however, indicates a weaker circulation (by about 50%), which is inconsistent with the PMIP3 simulations and questions the reliability of these models for future MOC projections. We have shown that increased winds over the North Atlantic caused by the presence of large ice sheets over North America increase the wind driven northward salt transport in the MOC in the Atlantic. We conclude that other processes such as changes in surface buoyancy fluxes must have been responsible for decreasing the ocean circulation during the LGM.

Experiments with the Transport Matrix Method (TMM) show that the data constraint circulation contributes 10-20 ppm to the lowering of atmospheric pCO2 during the LGM. Further 40 ppm are caused by colder temperatures. Another 15-20 ppm decrease is estimated due to increased whole ocean alkalinity by fitting modeled carbonate ion concentrations to reconstructions. These processes together explain ~80% of the observed pCO2 difference. The effect of iron fertilization remains to be quantified, but has the potential to explain the remaining 20%. 

Detailed analysis of the carbon cycle indicates an important contribution from disequilibrium effects and tentatively suggests that the biological pump may not have been increased (much) during the LGM. This analysis also indicates that estimates of biologically sequestered carbon using apparent oxygen utliization, which has been done frequently in the past, suffer from large errors and should be avoided for glacial-interglacial differences.

Changes in radiocarbon age are shown to be qualitatively different from changes in ideal age due to effects of air-sea gas exchange. Whereas simulated radiocarbon ages are 500 years older during the LGM, consistent with, but slighly lower than global estimates from reconstructions (600-700 years), ideal ages were younger. This questions direct inferrences on circulation rates from radiocarbon reconstructions.

In summary, we have made important progress in understanding the glacial ocean circulation, its driving forces, its carbon cycle, and its effects on atmospheric pCO2.

Broader Impacts

A workshop entitled "PMIP Ocean Workshop 2013: Understanding Changes Since the Last Glacial Maximum" brought together paleoceanographers, other paleoclimate scientists, and modelers, and fostered international and interdisciplinary collaboration. Important outcomes of this workshop were the initiation of two new international projects focused on a better understanding of the deglacial ocean through data synthesis and international collaboration:

  1. Ocean Circulation and Carbon Cycle (OC3), a Past Global Changes working group with the goal to synthesize ocean carbon isotope (δ13C) data, and
  2. Investigating Past Ocean Dynamics (IPODS), a focus group sponsored by the International Quaternary Association with the goal to synthesize radiocarbon and other proxies of ocean circulation.

OC3 and IPODS had their joint inaugural meeting on October 1-3 in Bern, Switzerland. IPODS had a subsequent workshop on August 26-27 in Utrecht, Netherlands. OC3 has already started compiling core-top and published down-core δ13C data and has led to a new funded NSF project (The Biological Pump During the Last Glacial Maximum and Early Deglaciation, award 1634719) and is planning a workshop in the summer of 2017. IPODS has finished a global compilation of LGM radiocarbon data. All workshops supported early career scientists and researchers from developing countries.
